editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

note.p: K2v begins "As when she ..". Early variant: K2v omits this line and begins "Wi. I am ..".
The title page is mostly in the same setting as STC 22442.

div.p: As it was presented by her majesty's servants at the private house in drury-lane.
London. Printed by John Norton, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke. 1637.

div.head: Actus. i.
div.stage: Enter master Wilding; and mistress Penelope.

sp.speaker: Wild
sp.l: What need you be so coy now?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Pray collect
Yourself, remember what you are, and whose
You have a virtuous gentlewoman, think
Upon your faith to her.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Think of a fiddlestick.
While you put me in mind of what I am,
You quite forget yourself: my wife I allow
Your kinswoman far off, to whom a widow
Your father left you, with a handsome fortune,
Which by her marriage, I have in possession,
And you too; therefore as you hope to be
In due time worth a husband, think upon't:
I can deserve respect, then wisely use me,
As you would keep me.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: This is but a trial
Of my strength, for I know you have more charity,
(Should I consent) then shipwreck your own honour.
But take heed sir, how you proceed to jest
With frailty, lest too much disordering
your good thoughts, you forget and by degrees,
Lose your own innocence.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: I jest? you'd have me swear, and yet you should not think it such a wonder: to love â–ª come, shake off this frost, it spoils thee; your nature should be soft, and flexible; perhaps thou thinkst, I do not love thee heartily, I know not how to give thee better testimony, then by offering myself to thee if my wife-die, as ten to one she's not immortal, we may couple tother way.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.p: What argument is this to assure the truth of your affection to me, that break your vows to her?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Oh! great argument, and you observe: she was a widow when I married her, thou art a young maid, and handsome.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.p: Can you be so ingrateful, to punish whom you should reward, remember sir, she brought you that wealth you have â–ª took you from nothing â€”

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: There's reason then for nothing I should love her: hang her estate, I was held a proper man, and in that point, deserved her, and she had millions: and I were free again. I would not draw i'th team of marriage for ten ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ not to command a province.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.p: Yet you said, were your wife dead you'd marry me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Only thee, and nobody else.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.p: 'Twere dangerous to: have many.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: To have one, is little less than madness; come, wilt promise? Enter mistress Wilding.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A course, you know my meaning.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: I do not like this whispering, why with her
So close in parley?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Wilt thou do this feat for me?
'Tis finished in a pair of minutes.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Yes, upon one condition.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What condition?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: That your wife give consent, you shall then command me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I'll undertake to go a pilgrimage
To Jerusalem, and return sooner: wood
I did not love thee, love thee infinitely,
That's all, 'Two not do â€” my wife, I hope. Exit Pene.
She has not eavesdropped, us; what pity 'tis
She cannot find the way to heaven; I should not
Trouble her in haste, these wives will have no conscience,
But stick to us everlastingly. Now lady,
How did your monkey rest last night, you look
As you had not done your prayers yet, I wonot disturb you.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Pray sir stay, let me but know
Some reason why you use me thus unkindly?
If I have been guilty of offence, I am not
Past hope, but with the knowledge of my error,
'Tis possible I may amend, and please you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I do not like you.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: You did marry me.

sp.speaker: Wi,
sp.l: Yes, I did marry you; here's too much record for't,
I would there were a parson to unmarry us,
If any of our clergy had â–ª that faculty,
He might repair the old; and build as many
New abbeys through the kingdom in a twelvemonth.
Shall I speak truth? I never much affected thee,
I married thee for thy soul's sake, not thy body,
And shall as soon get children on't: and yet
I do not hate thee, witness, I dare kiss,
Hold thee by the hand, and sleep in the same house,
And in thy bed sometimes, something has been done.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Within the memory of man, but â€”
What sir?

sp.speaker: Wi
sp.l: You have a scurvy quality wife, I told you on't.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Once more, and I'll correct it.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: You are given to be jealous, I cannot
Ramble abroad in gentlemen's company
Whole days, lie out a nights, but you suspect
I am wanton, 'tis ill done, it becomes no modest
Woman: that loves her husband, to be jealous,
Whate'er she see, or hears, mend, mend this fault,
You do not know, how it may work upon me.
Some wife will bid her husband's leverets welcome,
Keep house together, and provide clean sheets,
And cullises to fortify; you ne'er did it:
Know her own chamber and not come forth â–ª
Till she be sent for; if her husband kiss her,
sometimes, allow her clothes and other trinkets,
Suffer her carve at table, she is satisfied,
And none o'th parish talk, she carries it
So handsomely: these morals I have read
Before now, but you put them not in practice,
Nor for ought I perceive, have disposition to't,
Therefore I'll take my course.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: To show I can
Be obedient to my griefs, from this time, sir,
I wonot urge with one unwelcome syllable,
How much I am neglected, I'll conceal it
Too from the world, your shame must needs be mine.
I see you do not love me, where your heart
Hath placed a worthier thought, let it dwell ever,
Freely pursue your pleasures, I will have
No passion that shall mutiny, you are,
And shall be lord of me still.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I like this, if it be no disguise.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Do not suspect me,
I would swear by a kiss, if you vouchsafe it,
You shall not keep a servant, that shall be more humble â–ª

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: And obedient to my will?

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: In all things.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: But if I bring home a mistress?

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: I'll call her sister.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What if there be one
Already, that does please me, will you not
Repine, and look awry upon's, when we
Make much of one another?

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: So you will but sometimes smile on me too, I'll endeavour.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Well said, this may do good upon me â–ª as
I find you prompt in this, I may consider
Other matters: to tell you true, I love
Your kinswoman.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I'th way you wot on, but
I find her cold and peevish, how she may
Be brought about I know not, 'twould show well,
And be a precedent for other wives,
If you would put your help to't.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Goodness bless me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: One woman with another can do more
In such a cause, than twenty men. I do not
Wander, you see, out of the blood, this will
Be a way to justify your obedience.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: You show a tyrant now, and stead of framing
My soul to patience, murder both. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I have gone too far a conscience; this may
Spoil all, and now I think upon't, I was
A coxcomb to discover any party,
I must deny't again, and carry things
More closely. How now will? Enter Hazard.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: How now will? Is that all?
Look up, and ask me a question like a man,
What melancholy?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No, no; a toy, a trifle.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: That should be a woman, who 'st thou art thinking on?
I have been of your counsel.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I was thinking, of my wife â€”

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I met her sad.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I cannot blame her;
We have had a dialogue; come, thou knowest my bosom,

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: When dost mean to lie with her?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I know not, but I have offered fair conditions:
She is very confident, I do not dote
Upon her beauty, I have told her, sirrah,
I love her kinswoman.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You're not so mad.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: The worlds deceived in her, she'll give me leave,
To ramble where I list, and feed upon
What best delights my appetite.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: He that has
An ambition to be strangled in his sleep,
May tell his wife he loves another â–ª woman.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: But I was not content with this, because
The other wench was somewhat obstinate,
I must needs urge my wife, to mollify
And mould her, for my purpose.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: And she consented too?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No 'twould not do.
This went against her stomach and we parted.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Next time you see her, look to be presented
With your mistress's nose for this, dost think a woman
can be so patient, to know her rival
I'th same roof, and leave her eyes, to see thee
Again? I am sorry for thee.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I am confident
She dare not: but for all that, would I had
Been less particular.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Come, I love thee well,
But not thy wit, to carry things no handsomer:
You must unravel again, and make your wife
Believe you did but try her.
How now, what's the news here?

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: Quickly to a surgeon, bear him gently.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What's the business.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: Nothing, sir, but a gentleman is killed, and we are
Carrying him to a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: 'Tis Jack Delamore, he is not dead.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Who hurt him?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Master Beamont; we cannot stay, sir.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Why they were friends.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: But wine made them fall out, some say, about
Their mistresses.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I did expect a woman at one end on't.
What miserable fools are men, to kill
One another for these cockatrices!

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am sorry for poor Beamont.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: It would be long ere any mistress would
Be so desperate for her servant, this is valour,
High and mighty valour.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Men must preserve
Their honour's man, thou dost not know their quarrel?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Thou art held a piece of a kill-cow too, look to't before the sessions take an order w'ee: is't not a great deal safer, now to skirmish with a petticoat, and touse a handsome wench in private; then be valiant in the streets, and kiss the gallows for't? hang, hang this foolery, let gentlemen rather live, and pay their tailors, then let their clothes enrich the hangman's wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: But skirmishing as you call it, with the petticoat,
Is by some, held away to this preferment,
your wench's ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ been sticklers, and some men
Dropped in their quarrel.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Let them be such coxcombs
They cannot die too soon; cannot I have
A lady of pleasure, but to please her humour,
I must be engaged to fight and kill men for her?
Because her healths refused, another's nose
Or teeth preferred, substantial grounds for murder,
We spend our blood too much another way;
Consumption take me, if I fight for one on 'em,
I will drink single beer first, and live honest,
Gentlemen are come to a fine pass, do not you
Think but 'tis possible, I may fight for all this?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: There may be causes, that have women in 'em,
But I confess, no polecats, or lewd strumpets,
Though I do use the trick o'th flesh, shall drive
Me to the surgeon; I had a mother.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: And I have a wife, would thou hadst her.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: No, no, she is well as she is,
There may be honour to defend these.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Sometimes.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: But there's a mischief greater than all these
A base and sordid provocation,
Used among gentlemen, they cannot quarrel
About a glass of wine, but our files streigth
Son of a whore, dead mothers must be torn,
Out of their graves, or living, have their names
Poisoned by a prodigious breath: it were
A brave and noble law, to make this tongue
Be cut for't, it would save much blood ith' year,
That might be spent more honourably.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: The lie grew a dull provocation, this has quickened us, but leave this common place, thou canst not help it, let's talk of something else. Stay is not this Beaumont?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Apprehended, alas poor gentleman; how now Ned?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: As you see gentlemen, called to my account.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: We heard a piece of the misfortune, but
Be not dejected, he may live.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I fear it.

Pray lead me where you please, alas. Violante! this news will
wound thee too. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I'll with him, and know the story.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: 'Twill but trouble me
I can do him no service, beside that,
I am engaged to meet old master Barnacle.
Whither, whither gentlemen, with your swords drawn?

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: Dost not see a gentleman led to prison?
We'll rescue him from the officers, come join with us:
We shall draw more to the cause.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You do not mean
This rashness: hide your swords be advised better;
D'ye know his fact?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: He has slain a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: They say he is not dead, the wounds not mortal.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: And will you make one past cure?

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: How dost mean?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Upon yourselves, cool your hot bloods a little,
No mutiny my country men, remember,
If he recover that is hurt, the tother
Will come off well enough, without your valour:
Breath, breathe a while, you may if you have a mind to't
Instead of rescuing, betray a gentleman,
And yourselves too, to a danger.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: He says right.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: 'Tis scurvy wearing hemp, if you scape killing,
There be more butchers than sell flesh; and citizens
Have no mercy in their clubs, especially
When gentlemen have so little wit, to bring
There heads to'th knocking down, 'tis a revenge
They owe you for their wives, o take heed mainly
Of these left handed halberdiers.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: Confound 'em.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: How many will you kill with your bird-spit?
You have more legs and arms at home, which makes
You valiant, I'll not pare my nails today,
And yet I love my friend, as the best on you;
You know I dare fight too, but in this cause
You must needs pardon me, I believe the stoutest
That now would seem all fire, and sword, will go
With as ill will to hanging, as another,
And will becom't as scurvily, take your courses.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I think 'tis better:

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: O'th two, to go to the tavern, and be drunk
In your own defence, a wench is not so dangerous
Nor the disease that waits upon her.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: What if the gentleman that's hurt should die?
Then there's no hope for tother.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Less for you,
You would be guilty of his murder too,
And snatch him from the law, why you may do't:
'Tis pity but the government should thank you,
And if you scape the halter for't, it may be
Another man in time, may cut your throat,
And there's one for another, paid in the blood.
Come be yourselves, these are not acts of gentlemen,
Where shame, not honour must reward your daring,
Though we be wild, it follows not we should
Be mad outright.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: I was ever of his mind.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: Come let's to tavern.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am for that coast, now I think upon't
I'll meet you at the new rendezvous within
This half-hour, I expect a gentleman
That has engaged my promise; I'll come t'ee
Ere you be half drunk.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Do not fail.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Drink sack and think not on't, what should be
The business that old barnacle has desired
My conference? 'tis not to lend me money sure,
He's here.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Master hazard.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I was coming to you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am fortunate to prevent so great a trouble,
There is a business, sir, wherein I must desire your favour.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Mine? command it, sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay I'll be thankful too, I know you are
A gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: That should incline, you think
I am not mercenary

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I beseech you, sir,
Mistake me not, rewards are due to virtues,
And honour must be cherished.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What's your purpose?
Pray clear my understanding.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: To be plain, sir,
You have a name i'th town for a brave fellow.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: How, sir, you do not come to jeer me?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Patience, I mean you have the opinion
Of a valiant gentleman, one that dares
Fight and maintain your honour against odds,
The swordmen do acknowledge you, the baylies
Observe their distance, all the swaggering pusses
Strike their topsails, I have heard 'em in the streets
Say there goes daring hazard, a man careless
Of wounds, and though he have not had the luck
To kill so many as another, dares
Fight with all them that have.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You have heard this.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: And more, and more, mistake not.
I do not all this while account you in
The list of those are called the blades, that roar
In brothels, and break windows, fright the streets
At midnight worse than constables, and sometimes
Set upon innocent bellmen, to beget
Discourse for a week's diet, that swear, dams,
To pay their debts, and march like walking armouries,
With poniard, pistol, rapier, and baton,
As they would murder all the King's liege people,
And blow down streets; no I repute you valiant
Indeed, and honoured, and come now without
More ceremony, to desire your favour;
Which as you are a gentleman, I hope,
You'll not deny me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Though your language
Be something strange, yet, because I think you dare not
Intend me an abuse, I wonot question it,
Pray to the point, I do not think, you're come
To have me be your second.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.l: I am no fighter,
Though I have seen a fence-school in my days,
And cracked a cudgel, yet I come about
A fighting business.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You would have me beat somebody for you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Not so noble hazard, yet
I come to entreat a valiant courtesy,
Which I am willing to requite in money,
I have brought gold to give you payment, sir,
'Tis a thing you may easily consent to,
And 'twill oblige me ever.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Be particular.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Then thus you are not ignorant I have a nephew, sir.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You have so.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: One that's like
To be my heir, the only of my name
That's left, and one that may in time be made
A pretty fellow.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Very well, proceed.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: You know or you imagine, that I have.
A pretty estate too.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You're held a main rich man, sir,
In money able to weigh down an alderman.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I have more than I shall spend; now I come close,
I would have this nephew of mine, converse with gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: And he does so.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I'll not pinch him in's allowance,
The university had almost spoilt him.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: With what?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: With modesty a thing you know
Not here in fashion, but that's almost cured,
I would allow him to be drunk.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You may, sir.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Or any thing to speak him a fine gentleman,

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: With your favour, sir, let me be bold a little
To interrupt you, were not you a citizen?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: 'Tis confessed, sir.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: It being a thriving way
A walk wherein you might direct your nephew,
Why d'ye not breed him so?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I apprehend;
And thus I satisfy you, we that had
Our breeding from a trade, cits as you call us,
Though we hate gentlemen ourselves, yet are
Ambitious, to make all our children gentlemen,
In three generations they return again,
we for our children purchase land, they brave it
I'th country, begets children, and they sell,
Grow poor, and send their sons up to be prentices:
There is a whirl in fate, the courtiers make
Us cuckolds; mark, we wriggle into their
Estates, poverty makes their children citizens;
Our sons cuckold them, a circular justice,
The world turns round, but once more to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: To your nephew.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: This nephew of mine, I do love dear;
He is all my care, I would be loath to lose him,
And to preserve him both in life, and honour:
I come to you.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Now you come to me indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What shall I give you, sir, to let him â€”

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Pray be not angry.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: By no means.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: There is no such security i'th world,
I'll pay for't heartily.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: What shall I give you troth, and let him.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Beat you, sir?

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Nay do not, sir, mistake me, for although
I name it, caursely I desire it should be
With your consent, no otherwise; my nephew
Is raw, and wants opinion, and the talk
Of such a thing, to beat a gentleman,
That all the towns afraid of, would be worth
In's credit, heaven knows what, alas you cannot
Blame a kind uncle, to desire all means
To get his nephew fame, and keep him safe,
And this were such a way.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: To have me beaten.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: You're i'th right, but do not misconceive me â–ª
Under your favour, my intention is not
He should much hurt you, if you please to let him
Quarrel, or so at tavern, or where else
You shall think fit, and throw a pottle-pot â€”

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: At my head.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Yes, or say it be a quart, still under your correction,
Only that some of your acquaintance and
gentlemen may take notice, that he dares
Affront you, and come off with honour handsomely,
Look here's a hundred pieces, tell, 'em i'th ordinary
They're weight upon my credit, play 'em not
Against light gold, this is the prologue to
My thanks, beside my nephew shall in private
Acknowledge himself beholding.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: A hundred pieces! I want money.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You give me this to let your nephew beat me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Pray take me w'ee, I do not mean he should
By beating, hurt you dangerously, you may
Contrive the quarrel, so that he may draw
Some blood, or knock you, o'er the pate, and so forth,
And come of bravely, this is all.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Well, sir,
You do not mean, you say he should endanger
My life or limbs; all you desire, if I
Mistake not, is to get your nephew credit,
That being fleshed, he may walk securely, and be held
Valiant by gaining honour upon me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You understand me right.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I'll put it up,
Pray send your nephew to me, we'll agree.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Agree, sir? you must quarrel, and he must beat you, else, 'tis no bargain.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Not before
We have concluded how things shall be carried.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I must desire your secrecy and â€”

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And there's my money.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Your nephew shall be a blade.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Why there's ten pieces more, cause you come off
So freely, I'll send him to you.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Do so, why this, if the dice favour me may bring all
My lands again, be sure you send him, but
No words for your nephew's credit.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Mum â€” I thank you heartily. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Be there such things i'th world, I'll first to the tavern,
There I am stayed for, gentlemen I come,
I'll be beaten every day for such a sum. Eixt.

div.head: Act. ii.
div.stage: Enter mistress Wilding, and the page.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Where's your master, boy?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I know not mistress.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Come nearer, sirrah, you are of your master's
Counsel sometimes, come, be true in what
I shall desire, and I shall find a time, for your reward.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: How d'ye mean mistress?
We pages meet rewards of several natures,
This great man gives us gold, that lady gloves,
Tother silk stockings, roses, garters: but
The lady, and mistress whom we serve in ordinary,
Reserves another bounty, for our closeness.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: I see you can be a wag, but be just to me, and secret.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: As your physician, or your looking-glass;
That in your absence cannot be corrupted
To betray your complexion.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: What private mistresses, does master Wilding visit?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Who my master?
Alas forsooth, d'ye think he lets me know?

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Nay, nay dissemble not.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I hire a coach
Sometimes, or so, but ride always i'th boot,
I look at nobody but the passengers,
I do not sit i'th same box at plays with him.
I wait at tavern, I confess, and so forth,
And when he has supped, we must have time to eat too,
And what should I trouble my conscience,
With being too officious, till I am called for?
'Tis true, he waits upon the ladies home,
But 'tis so dark, I know not where they dwell,
And the next day we have new ones, 'las mere strangers
To me, and I should be unmannerly
To catechise 'em, if now, and then, there be
Any superfluous cast waiting-woman,
There be so many serving men about her,
I cannot come to ask a question,
And how should I know any thing?

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: I see you are old enough for vice.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Alas forsooth,
You know 'tis ill to do a thing that's wicked,
But 'twere a double sin to talk on't too,
If I were guilty; beside forsooth, I know
You would near trust me again, if I should tell you.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Thou art deceived, it shall endear thee more.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I must beseech you
To be excused, my master is my master,
My feet are at your service, not my tongue,
I would not forfeit my recognizance,
And shame the tribe, pages, and midwives are
Sworn to be close.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Hence thou old in villainy,
But 'tis in vain to chide, leave me, and bid
Mistress Penelope come hither.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: I know not which way to begin, to me
He has betrayed he loves her, she is present.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Will you be sad still cousin, why d'ye grieve?
Be kinder to yourself, trust me, I weep
When I am alone, for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Sorrow and I
Are taking leave I hope, and these are only
Some drops after the cloud has wept his violence:
Were one thing finished, I should ne'er be sad more,
And I cannot despair to know it done,
Since the effect depends upon your love.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: My love? 'tis justice you command my service,
I would I were so happy.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Make me so,
By your consent to my desire.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Pray name it.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: I only ask your love, pray give it me.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.p: My love? why do you mock my poor heart, which pours all it has upon you? you're possessed of that already.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: You examine not
The extent of my request, for when you have
given what I ask, your love, you must no more
Direct it, as you please, the power's in me
How to dispose it.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: And you shall for ever,
I have no passion that shall not know obedience to you.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Your love by gift
Made mine, I give my husband you, love him.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: I always did.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: But in a nearer way:
Love him as I do, with a resolution
To give yourself to him, if he desire it.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: I understand you not, or if you do
Suspect I cherish any lawless fame â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Thou art to innocent; be less, and do
An act to endear us both, I know he loves thee;
Meet it, dear coz, 'tis all I beg of thee;
I know you think it a most strange request,
But it will make fortunate.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Grief I fear
Hath made her wild, d'ye know what you desire?

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Yes, that you love my husband: modesty
Will not allow me to discourse my wish
In every circumstance, but think how desperate
My wound is, that would have so strange a cure,
He'll love me then, and trust me I'll not study
Revenge, as other wives perhaps would do,
But thank thee, and indeed an act like this;
So full of love, with so much loss and shame too,
For mine and his sake, will deserve all duty,

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: I have no patience to hear more, and could
I let in a thought, you meant this earnest,
I should forget I knew you; but you cannot
Be fallen from so much goodness, I confess
I have no confidence in your husband's virtue,
He has attempted me; but shall hope sooner
To leave a stain upon the sun, then bribe
Me to so foul a guilt; I have no life
Without my innocence, and you cannot make
Yourself more miserable, then to wish it from me:
o, do not lose the merit of your faith,
And truth to him, though he forget himself,
By thinking to relieve yourself thus sinfully,
But sure you do but try me all this while.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: And I have found thee pure, be still preserved so,
But he will straggle further â€”

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Cherish hope,
He rather will come back; your tears, and prayers
Cannot be lost.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: I charge thee by thy love,
Yet be ruled by me; I'll not be so wicked
To tempt thee in a thought shall blemish thee:
But as thou wouldst desire my peace, and his
Conversion, if his wantonness last with him,
Appear more tractable, allow him so much
Favour, in smile, or language, that he may not
Think it impossible to prevail at last.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: This may engage him further, and myself to a dishonour.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: It shall work our happiness,
As I will manage things; 'tis but to seem:
A look will cost thee nothing, nor a syllable
To make his hopes more pleasing, on my life
Thou shalt be safe both in thy fame, and person,
Will you do this for my sake?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: I'll refuse no danger, if I suffer not in honour,
To do you any service.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: I have cast it
Already, in my brain, but do not yet
Inquire my purpose, as his folly leads
Him to pursue you, let me know, and I'll
By fair degrees acquaint you with my plot,
Which built on no foul ends, is like to prosper,
And see how aptly he presents himself,
Prithee seem kind, and leave the rest to me.
He shall not see me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: How now coz? was that
My wife went off?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Let her go, what said she to thee?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thou art troubled.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Pray to your knowledge, sir, wherein have I
Done injury to you, or her?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Has she abused thee?
I'll go kick her.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: By no means, sir, I steal away your heart,
And meet at stolen embraces.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Does she twit thee? I'll kick her like a football,
Say but the word.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: By no means think upon't, I have forgiven her,
You sha'not sir, so much as frown upon her.
Pray do not as you love me,
We may study a more convenient revenge.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: How's this?
I prithee if she have been peremptory,
Which was none of our articles, let me instruct thee,
How we shall be revenged.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Sir, I acknowledge
The growth and expectation of my fortune,
Is in your love, and though I would not wrong her;
And yet to have my innocence accused
Is able to pervert it, sir, your pardon,
I have been passionate; pray love your wife,

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No, no, I'll love thee, indeed, indeed I will,
Is she jealous?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: You know she has no cause.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Let us be wise; and give her cause, shall's cozen,

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Sir, if it be a trouble to your house,
Your breath shall soon discharge me, I had thought
The tie of blood might have gained some respect.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Discharge thee the house? I'll discharge her,
And all her generation, thee excepted,
And thou shalt do't thyself, by this, thou shalt;
Ha, she kisses with more freedom, this is better,
Than if my wife had pleaded for me, pen,
Thou shalt be mistress, wilt? come thou shalt,
She's fit for drudgery.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: O, do not say so.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Then I wonot, but I love thee for thy spirit,
'Cause thou wilt be revenged, punish her jealousy
the right way, when 'tis done, I do not care
To tell her, it may kick up her heels too, another way.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Tell her what? you make me blush.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No, no, I'll tell nobody , by this hand.
Stay I have a diamond will become this finger,
Wear it, and let my wife stare out her eyes upon't.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: I wonot take't on such conditions.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Take it on any; she is come about.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Sir master hazard desires your company at tavern, he says there are none but gentlemen of your acquaintance, master Acre-less, master Littlestock, and master Sell-away, the three gamesters.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: He must excuse me.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: As you love me, go, sir.
Have no suspicion that I wish your absence,
I'll wear your gift, and study to be thankful. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Well, there's no great hurt in all this yet;
The tides not strong against me, no talk now,
Of wife's consent, I'll not remove my siege,
She'll study to be thankful, she's mine own,
As sure as I were in her maidenhead,
Now to the tavern boy, and drink to the purpose. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Hazard, Acre-less Little-stocke, Sell-away, as in a tavern. Drawers.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: More wine, is not this better gentlemen,
Then spitting constables? you would have fought now,
And had your brain-pans opened

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: Right noble hazard,
Here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Let come boy, fill it me steeple-high,
I am in vain of mirth, and I ha' cause
As you shall see in due time gentlemen.
Master little stock thou art dreaming o'th dice.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: He's melancholy.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Who I!

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: I'll play the farrier then, and drench thee for the sullens â–ª a health to all our mistresses, we have had 'em single, let's shuffle 'em now together.
Master Acre-less.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: Will't please you gentlemen to have a song.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You have not washed today, go get clean manners;
You rascal we have no wenches.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: I see nobody , sir, you have washed my eyes out.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: It is not necessary thou shouldst have any:
Fill me again.

sp.speaker: Acr,
sp.l: This fellow would ha' tother cup.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: I have had a cup too much already gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Let it go round, and then in hope you may
Look double, I'll show you a sight, I wonder
Jack Wilding stays.
He's come i'th nick.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Save, save you gallants, may a man come i'th rear?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Give him his garnish.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: You're not prisoners for the reckoning, I hope.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: For the reckoning? now you're altogether gentlemen,
I'll show you a wonder â–ª but come not too near,
Keep out o'th circle, whatsoever you think on't,
This is a hundred pound, nay, not so close,
These pictures do show best at distance, gentlemen.
You see it, presto â€”

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Nay let's see't again.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Like to your cunning juggler, I never show
My trick but once you may hear more hereafter,
What think you of this master Acre-less, master Littlestock,
And master Sell-away?

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: We do not believe 'tis gold,

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Perish then
In your infidelity.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Let me but touch it.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: It will endure, take my word for't, why look you,
For your satisfactions, no gloves off,
You have devices to defalk, preserve
Your talons, and your talents, till you meet
With more convenient gamesters.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: How cam'st by it?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thou'dst little or none this morning.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I have bought it gentlemen, and you in a mist
Shall see what I paid for it, thou hast not drunk yet:
Ne'er fear the reckoning man, more wine, you varlets,
and call your mistress, your scolopendia
If we like her complexion, we may dine here.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: But hark thee, hark thee will, didst win it?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: No, but I may lose it ere I go to bed,
Dost think't shall musty, what's a hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Sel,
sp.l: A miracle, but they are ceased with me.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: And me too, come let's drink.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No matter, how it came will, I congratulate
Thy fortune, and will quit thee now
With good news of myself, my coz I told thee on,
Is wheeled about, she has taken a ring o'me,
We kissed, and talked, time out a mind.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I know it,
My almanac says 'tis a good day to woo in,
Confirmed by erra pater, that honest Jew too,
I'll pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Master hazard there are two gentlemen below,
Inquire for you.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: For me?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: One's somewhat ancient, I heard him call
The tother nephew.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Say I come to 'em presently,
Gentlemen, I do caution you before
To be fair conditioned: one of them, the nephew
Is of a fiery constitution,
And sensible of any affront, let this
Character prepare him for you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Bring him not hither.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: There is a necessity in't, I would not for
A hundred pound but entertain him, now
He knows I am here. Exit.

div.stage: Enter master Hazard again, with Barnacle, his nephew, and Dwindle.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: This is old barnacle.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: One that is too fine for alderman.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: And that's his nephew, I have been in's company,

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Is this the youth hazard prepared us for?
How busy they are?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You could not wish better opportunity,
These are all gentlemen of quality,
I'll call him cozen first, if it please you,
To endear him to their acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I'll not be a witness of your passages myself; these will report as much as I desire, sir, if you be beaten I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: But d'ye hear uncle, are sure you have made
Your bargain wisely; they may cut my throat
When you are gone, and what are you the wiser,
Dwindle be you close to me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I warrant you we shall do things with discretion,
If he have but grace, to look and talk courageously.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He may be valiant for ought I know,
Howsoever this will be a secure way
To have him thought so, if he beat you soundly.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: I do not like the company;
But I have drunk wine too, and that's the best on't,
We may quarrel on even terms, look to
Thy basket-hilt Dwindle, and have a stool ready;

sp.speaker: Dw.
sp.l: I will give your worship a stool.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: As I am gentleman, be confident
I'll wait on you down, sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: By no means, let him beat you to purpose, sir.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Buy uncle. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Come, sir, pray gentlemen, bid my kinsman welcome: a spark that will deserve your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: His kinsman? you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: He has power to command your welcome.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: If I mistake not, I have had the happiness
To ha' been in your company afore now.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Mine, sir? d'ye hear, what if I quarrelled
With him first? 'twill prepare me the better.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Do as you please; that's without my conditions.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: I'll but give him now and then a touch, I'll close
Well enough I warrant you, you been in my
Company, sir?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Yes, and at the tavern.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: I paid the reckoning then.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: You came into our room â€”

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Tell me of coming into your room,
I'll come again, you are a superfluous gentleman,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Let him alone.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Sir, remember yourself.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: I'll remember what I please, I'll forget what
I remember: tell me of a reckoning, what is't?
I'll pay't, no man shall make an ass of me,
Further than I list myself, I care not a fiddle -
Stick for any man's thundering, he that affronts
Me, is the son of a worm, and his father a
Whore, I care not a straw, nor a broken point
For you, if any man dare drink to me; I
Wonot go behind the door to pledge him.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: Why here's to you, sir,

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Why there's to you, sir.
sp.p: Twit me with coming into a room, I could â€” find in my heart, to throw a pottle-pot, I name nobody , I will kick any man down stairs, that cannot behave himself like a gentleman, none but a slave would offer to pay a reckoning before me, where's the drawer? there's a piece at all adventures; he that is my friend, I cars not a rush, if any man be my enemy, he is an idle companion, and I honour him with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: This is a precious humour, is he used to these mistakes?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Your kinsman gives him privilege.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: I desire no man's privilege, it skills not whether I be kin to any man living.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Nay, nay, cozen, pray let me persuade you.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: You persuade me? for what acquaintance, mind your business and speak with your tailor.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: And you be thus rude â€”

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: Rude, sir, what then, sir, hold me dwindle.

sp.speaker: Dw.
sp.p: Are you ready to have a stool, sir?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Nay, nay, will, we bear with him for your sake,
He is your kinsman.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am calm again,
Cousin, I am sorry any person here
Hath given you offence.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Perhaps, sir, you
Have given me offence, I do not fear you,
I have knocked as round a fellow in my days.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: And may â–ª again â€”

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Be knocked, a pox upon him, I know not what to make on him.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Let me speak a word in private, sir.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: I can be as private as you, sir.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Strike me a box o'th ear presently.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: There's my hand on't.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Nay, nay, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: Master Wilding.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Let him call me to account, the reckonings paid.
Come Dwindle. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I did not think the fool durst ha' done this,
'Tis a strange youth.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You shall hear more tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: All's paid, and you are welcome gentlemen. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why should not we two live together, being
So equal in our passions? o Violante,
Our knowledge grew from children, and our love's
Ally us in our natures.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: 'Tis â–ª my wish
To dwell with thee, I never knew that woman
In whom I took more pleasure to converse with,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But I have a father, and remembering him
A sorrow steals upon me, to betray
My hopes of blessing; for although he love me,
And dear as he says, for children must not
Dispute with fathers, he affects not him
In whom I place all thoughts that can delight me,
He loves not Delamore, and what to me
Is all the world without him? I shall never
I fear, have his consent to be made happy
In marriage, and this, although our thoughts
Reflect with equal honour on our lovers,
Makes the distinction, and concludes me miserable,
Thy will depends upon no riged parent,
Thy path is strewed with roses, while I climb
A ragged cliff, to meet whom I affect.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Indeed, Leonara I much pity thee.

sp.speaker: Leo,
sp.l: I prithee counsel me how shall I wrestle
With my sad destiny, and yet preserve
my filial obedience, I must lose
A father, or a husband.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Would I knew
Which way to bid thee steer, but lessoned by
My own affection, I would have thy mind
Constant to him thou lov'st, time may correct
A father's harshness, and be confident
If poor Violante have a power to serve thee,
She will forget her own heart, ere prove false to thee.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: O my dear soul, I know't.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: O mistress.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What's the matter!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: This face betrays some miserable accident.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Speak, and assure us, what disaster makes
Thy countenance so wild.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: A friend of yours â€”

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is sick, is dead, what more? and yet I have
So few, I can spare none.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Is dead, since you appear so fortified.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is my father living, and Delamore?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Your father is in health, but â€”

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Stay, as thou wouldst preserve thy mistress in
The number of the living.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: How my fears increase!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Except Violante, whom I see
Enjoys her health, I have no friend but Delamore,
I hope he is not dead.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Your Delamore is dead. She faints.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: Friend, Leonora,
'Twas indiscreetly done to open sorrow
So like a torrent, Leonora; friend.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why dost thou call me from him? sure I was
Going to meet my Delamore.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: Give not such
Belief to these sad news, until you hear it
Confirmed, didst see him dead?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I did not see him.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: Have comfort then, this may
Be checked again.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Would I could hope it.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Have more courage friend,
Didst hear the circumstance?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: He was slain they say.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Nay then believe it not, he was so innocent,
He could provoke no angry sword against him.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I wish your confidence were not deceived,
The last part of my story will concern
Your faith, and sorrow.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Mine? in her I share
Too much, but prithee since thou hast not been
Slow to wound her, let me know my affliction.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The general voice is, master Beaumont slew him,
Your servant lady.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Tell the general voice
It lies, my Beaumont prove a murderer?
And of his friend? he would not kill an enemy.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: All I can say in proof of this, I saw him
Guarded to prison, pardon my relation.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: If thou believest thy eyes abused thee not,
Thou mightst with one breath spoken 'em both dead,
For the survivor lives, but to give up
His life with more shame, all my comfort is,
I shall not live to see it, o Leonora,
Who is most wretched now? let thou, and I,
The few days that we have to live, be friends,
And die in perfect charity, I must leave you
To manage your own grief, I have enough
To break my poor heart too. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What seas break in
Upon us? I that could have died within
A gentle wave, now struggle for my life,
My father?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: What, it seems you heard the news,
Come let your sorrows dry up, you may see
What 'tis to be so rash, when you choose next,
You'll consult me, I hope; wipe, wipe your eyes,
Your tears are vain, I could say more.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What sir?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: They are more than he deserved, and yet 'tis better
Thou shouldst bestow thy tears upon his funeral,
Than I sighed at thy marriage; come, heaven has
Been kind in this divorce, preparing thus
Thy better fortune, and preserving mine,
I am sorry for the gentleman that killed him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: O murderer.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: You are a fool, and know not
His provocation: in my youthful days,
I was not patient when affronts were offered me,
Nothing more dear to gentlemen, than honour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Honour in murder?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: This was otherwise:
In my own defence I would kill a family,
He showed his generous spirit, all the town
Speaks nobly of him, pity him, and pray for him,
And were he not desertful, by this time
The general vote had hanged him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: O, my fate!

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Tother a loose, and inconsiderate man,
Lost in estate, and would ha' married thee,
To ha' squeezed mine, 'tis better as it is.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Good sir, be charitable to the dead.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Be you first charitable to the living.
Speak well, and think so too, you do not know
What benefit may follow, and howe'er
Your womanish sorrow for the present may
So mist your eyes, they will hereafter open,
To see, and thank my care.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Indeed your language,
Pardon my boldness, sir, is dark and mystical.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: You have your wit to apprehend sometimes,
But 'tis not passion must excuse your duty to me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I hope.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Your hopes may fail you if you do,
Be obedient hereafter, if you please,
And love my directions

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I'll not have
a thought shall disobey you, and if ever
I love again.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: If ever? why suppose
I should propound one to you, now i'th heat
Of this misfortune, can your heart be obstinate
To me, and your own good?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: This is too soon
A conscience, sir, before his blood be cold,
To whom I professed love, to like another?
The world would much condemn me.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Is the world
Or I to be preferred, this makes the act
Of your obedience perfect, and because
I'll have assurance of what power I hold,
This minute I'll prefer one to your thoughts,
Dispose your heart to love the gentleman
That now's in prison.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Whom d'ye mean dear sir?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: He that killed Delamore, master Beaumont:
Do not suspect I trifle, he is of
A noble house, of a fair expectation,
Handsome in every part.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Shall not he suffer
For the black deed already done?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Compose
Yourself to love him, I'll find a way how to
Secure his life, and bring him freely off.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Oh! consider ere you move to far;
If having slain my comfort, for I must
Give it no other name, call not your justice
To my revenge, yet let me not be forced,
To have a thought so full of shame to women,
That he should be my husband, 'tis a stain
Time nor repentance can wash off, I know
You cannot mean so cruelly, beside
I shall commit a sin, foul as his murder,
Upon poor Violante, and rob her:
Their heart's love hath sealed up i'th eye of heaven,
'Twere sacrilege to part 'em, she's my friend too,
one that will rather die than injure me.
And he will rather suffer, if he be
Noble as you profess him, then consent to
So foul a guilt.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Let me alone for that,
If he refuse this offer for his life,
Why let him die, I'll put him to't, consider,
In this I shall behold thy naked soul,
Be ruled, and prosper; disobey, and be
Thrown from my care and blood, at better leisure
I'll tell you more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Has heaven no pity for me?
What killing language doth a father speak?
Poor heart prevent more grief, and quickly break. Exit.

div.head: Act. iii.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: This humour does become thee, I knew when
Thou didst consider, what was offered thee;
Thy sullenness wood shake off, now thou lookest
Fresher than morning, in thy melancholy
Thy clothes became thee not.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: You're i'th right,
I blamed my tailor for't, but I find now,
The fault was in my countenance, would we had
Some music, I could dance now, la, la, la, bram, etc.,

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Excellent! and she be a-bed but half so nimble,
I shall have a fine time on't; how she glides?
Thou wot not fail?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: This night â€”

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: At the hour of twelve.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: But you must be as punctual ith' conditions
For my vow's sake, not speak a syllable.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I'll rather cut my tongue out then offend thee,
Kissing is no language.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: If it be not too loud;
We must not be seen together, to avoid
suspicion, I would not for a world my cousin
Should know on't.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: She shall die in ignorance.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: No piece of a candle.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: The devil shall not see us
With his saucer eyes; and if he stumble in
The dark, there sha'not be a stone ith' chamber,
To strike out fire with's horns; all things shall be
So close; no lightning shall peep in upon us,
O, how I long for midnight!

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: I have a scruple.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: O, by no means, no scruples now.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: When you
Have your desires upon me, you will soon
Grow cold in your affection, and neglect me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Why hang me if I do, I'll love thee ever:
I have cast already, to preserve thy honour,
Thou shalt be married in a fortnight, coz,
Let me alone to find thee out a husband,
Handsome and fit enough, we will love then too.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: When I am married?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Without fear or wit
Cum privilegio, when thou hast a husband,
Dost think I will forsake thee pen? 'twere pity
A my life, sweet, o there is no pleasure
To those embraces; I shall love thee better,
And the assurance that thou hast two fathers
Before thou hast a child, will make thee spring
More active in my arms, and I tell thee,
'Tis my ambition to make a cuckold,
The only pleasure o'th world: I would not
Wish to enjoy thee now, but in the hope
Of tother harvest, and to make thy husband
Hereafter cuckold, that imagination
Sweetness the rest, and I do love it mainly, mainly.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: 'Tis double sin.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: 'Tis treble pleasure wench;
But we lose time, and may endanger thus
My wife into a jealousy, if she see us,
farewell, farewell dear pen. at night remember,
I wonot lose my sport for half the country. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs Wi.
sp.l: Thou hast hit my instructions excellently.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: I have made work for somebody , you have put me
Upon a desperate service, if you do not
Relieve me, I am finely served.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: All has succeeded to my wish, thy place
I will supply tonight , if he observe
All the conditions, I may deceive
My husband into kindness; and we both
Live to reward thee better, o, dear coz!
Take heed by my example, upon whom
Thou placest thy affection.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Master hazard.

sp.speaker: Ha
sp.l: Save mistress Wilding.

sp.speaker: Mrs Wi.
sp.l: You are welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: He is a handsome gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Gone abroad?

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: I am not certain, I'll inquire.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Your servant
Ha! this is the frosty gentlewoman, in good time,
I care not if I cast away some words on her,
And yet she's so precise, and over honest,
I had as good never attempt her, your name is
Penelope, I take it lady.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: If you take it,
I hope you'll give it me again.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What again?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: My name.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What should I do wot?
No, no, keep thy name,
Howe'er thou dost thy maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Can you tell me
Of any honest man that I may trust with it?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I'll tell thee a hundred.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Take heed what you say, sir.
A hundred honest men, why if there were
So many i'th city, 'twere enough to forfeit
their charter; but perhaps you live in the suburbs.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: This wench will jeer me.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: I hope you are not one, sir.

sp.speaker: Ha,
sp.l: One of what?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: One of those honest men you talked of so,
One to whose trust, a virgin might commit
A maidenhead, as you call it.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Yes, you may trust me,
I have possessed a hundred maidenheads.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: How long?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Nay, nay; they are no commodities to keep,
No fault of ours: truth is, they're not worth
Preserving, some of your own sex acknowledge it,
And yet by your complexion, you have yours still,
Away with't, and in time.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Why you are modest.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You've hit me lady: come, I'll give thee counsel;
And more, I'll help thee to a chapman too,
Besides whate'er he pays for't, shall be at charge
To mould it of himself; how light thou'lt be
Without thy maidenhead, dost not spoil thy sleep
And breed the nightmare?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Who can help it, you
Gentlemen are such strange creatures, so unnatural,
So infinitely chaste, so mortified
With beef and barleywater, such strange discipline,
And haircloth.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Who wears haircloth? gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Such severe ways to tame your flesh, such friends
To Fridays, lent, and ember-weeks; such enemies
To sack, and marrow-pies, candles, and crabs,
Fiddlers, and other warm restoratives,
A handsome woman can not reach your pity,
sp.p: We may e'en grow to our pillows, ere you'll comfort us; this was not wont.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Not wont to be, in my
Remembrance lady.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: You are a handsome gentleman
Why may not you drink wine sometimes, or eat
sturgeon, or forage in your lusty-pie
Of artichoke, or potato; or why may not
Your learned physician dictate ambergris,
Or powders, and you obey him, in your broths?
Have you so strange antipathy to women?
To what end will gentlemen
Come to, if this frost hold?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You are witty â–ª
But I suppose you have no cause of such
Complaint, however some men do want heat,
Their is no general winter; I know a gentleman
Can drink, and eat, and bear you company
A-bed , for all your jeering: do not think
'Tis I: thou shall recant this profane talk
And woo me for a kiss, ere I'll stoop to thee.
Here's none but friends, if master Wilding ha' not
Told you already, I will justify
'Tis possible, you may be got with child.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: By him, you are but cozens afar off,
If you allow't, he need not travel far
For other dispensation, what say to him?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Was this at his entreaty?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: My own mere motion
And good will towards him, cause I know his mind.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: You are a fine gentleman, where's your land?
You may be knight o'th shire in time: farewell, sir.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I know not what to make on her, she may beExit.
A tumbler, for all this, I'll to her again. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Nay, nay, be comforted, and mistake me not,
I did not mention Delamore to provoke
These tears: he's gone, think on your living friends.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: If you be one, good sir â€”

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Yes, I am one:
And yet mistake me not, I do not come
A-wooing for myself, I am past tilting,
But for my nephew, o that nephew of mine!
I know sr. Richard hurry, you wise father,
will think well of him,
Nay, nay, weeping still.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It is too soon to think of any other.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: To soon to think of any other, why,
What woman of discretion, but is furnished
With a second husband ere the first be coffined?
He that stays till the funeral be past,
Is held a modest coxcomb, and why should not
Maids ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ as early in their provision?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I blush to think, my father of his mind,
Distressed Leonora good. sir lose
No more breath, I am resolved to die a virgin
I know not what love is.
And yet these tears
Are shed for one you loved.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He that was all
My treasure living, being lost must needs
Be a great part of sorrow: but my eyes
Though they can never pay to many drops
To the sad memory of Delamore,
Shed not all these for him, there is another
That makes me weep.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Another whom you love?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Heaven knows I never let into my heart,
Affection to a second, I am so far
From loving him, I wish we may ne'er meet,
I am not safe in my own bosom, while
I think upon him, it begets new springs
Within my eyes; which will in little time,
Rise to a flood, and drown me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I conceive
This is no friend of yours, come I'll relieve you,
Nay, and there be any man that troubles you,
If there be any you'd have talked withal,
I'll rid you of that care, he that shall offer
But to disturb you in a thought, d'ye mark me?
I'll take an order with him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What will you do?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do not mistake me neither, I'll do nothing,
but send my nephew, he shall top him,
And top him, and scourge him like a top too.
You know not how my nephew is improved
Since you last saw him, valiant as Hercules,
He has knocked the flower of chivalry, the very
Donzal deal Phebo of the time. and all
The blades do reverence him; I'll say no more,
Name but the man whom you do frown upon,
And let me send my nephew to him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sha'not need.
I have no enemy to engage his sword,
My discontents flow from a nearer person,
I grieve to say my father.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How? your father
Say but the word and I will send my nephew
To him, and he were ten fathers he can mollify him,
To please you lady, my nephew never spare him,
O, had you seen him baffle a squire this morning!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Pray no more, you shall do me a noble office.
To leave me to myself.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Mistress Violante
Is come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I wait upon her,
Your gentle pardon. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Would my nephew had her.
She is s. Richard's heir, and here he is.
S. Richard?

div.stage: Enter s. Richard Hurry, and surgeon.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: O master Barnacle, I'll wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That's master Probe the surgeon.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: No more you know my meaning.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Let him be buried.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I understand you, sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I have been discoursing
With your fair daughter.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Where is Leonora?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: She's within, sir.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Bid her come hither,
master Barnacle I am something troubled about a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And I am glad I met with you:
If you be troubled with any gentleman,
I'll send my nephew to him.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: To whom, or whither?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: To any man alive, I care not whither.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Send him to Jerusalem.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That's something o'th furthest, I shall be
Unwilling he should travel out o'th kingdom.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Leonera? Nearer â€”

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Who is that?
A pretty gentlewoman! save you mistress,
What is your name I pray?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I am called Violante.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Are you a maid?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I should be sorry else.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: D'ye know my nephew?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Not I, sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Not my nephew? how have you been bred?
Why he's the only gallant o'th town,
Please you I'll send him to you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: What to do, sir.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: He shall do any thing, the towns afraid on him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Oh! pray keep him from me then.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He'll hurt no women, but for the men â€”

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: There's one has hurt to much already.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What is he? I'll send my nephew to him lady,
If you have any occasion, never spare him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Not I, sir.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Look to't, and correct this humour.
I'll to him presently, master Barnacle,
Let me entreat your company to a gentleman,
I'll wait as much on you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You shall command me:
If't be to any man you care not for,
We'll take my nephew along. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: It sha' not need,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: O Violante! I
must now require some fruit of all thy promises.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: You hold me not suspected.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Leonora
Cannot be so ingrateful: but we have
Small limit for discourse, my father means
To visit Beaumont, now in prison, thou
Wilt hear too soon the story, and without
Prevention find thyself more miserable.
O Violante: I will suffer with him
Rather than injure thee, I prithee go
Visit thy friend, not mine, and as thou lovest me,
As thou lovest him, or thy own life, Violante,
Bid him be constant to thee, tell him what fame
Dwells upon noble lovers, that have sealed
Faith to their mistresses in blood: what glory
Can perjured men expect, that lose their honour
To save a poor breath? bid him be assured,
If for the hope of life, his soul can be
So much corrupted to embrace a thought
That I shall ever love him â€”

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: You Leonora?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Never, o, never; tell him so: by virtue,
And the cold blood of my slain Delamore,
Although my father threaten death.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Your father?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Make hast sweet Violante, to the prison;
There thou shalt know all, there thou shalt have proof
How much thou art beloved, and by my death,
If he prove false to thee, how much I love thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I am amazed, and my soul much distracted
Twixt grief, and wonder, it grows late i'th morning,
I le visit the sad prisoner, my heart trembles,
More can but kill me too, I'm, fit to die,
And woes but hasten immortality. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: How now? what gamesters?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Little to any purpose yet, but we
Expect deep play tonight .

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Will hazard, I have been seeking thee this
Two hours, and now I have found thee, avoid me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Thar't not infectious.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No, but I swell with my imaginations
Like a tall ship, bound for the fortunate lands;
Top, and top-gallant, my flags, and my fegaries
Upon me with a lusty gale of wind
Able to rend my sails, I shall o'errun,
And sink thy little bark of understanding
In my career boy.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Pray heaven rather
You do not spring a leak, and forfeit your
Ballast, my confident man of war, I
Have known as stout a ship been cast away
In sight o'th harbour.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: The wench, the wench boy.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: The vessel you have been chasing.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Has struck sail,
Is come in, and cries aboard my new lord of
The Mediterranean, we are agreed,
This is the precious night will; twelve the hour;
That I must take possession of all,
Of all; there are some articles agreed on.
Who's this?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Oh! the gamesters now come in:
That gay man is a lord, and with him Sell-away.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: They are well coupled, a lord and Sell-away.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: He wears good clothes you see, and in the street
More looked at then the pageants, he will talk little.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: To purpose.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Right, he cannot walk
Out of his cinquepace, and no man carries
Legs more in tune, he is danced now from his sempstress.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A man much bound to his tailor.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: And his barber.
He has a notable head.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Of hair thou meanest.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Which is sometime hung in more bride-laces
Than well would furnish out two country weddings

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Is he a scholar?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: 'Tis not necessary.
He is neither scholar, nor a courtier,
If report wrong him not.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Will. He plays money freely.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: With more pride than he wears embroidery.
'Tis his ambition to lose that: and
A wench maintains his swearing, let him pass.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What's next.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: A knight, and Acre-less.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Good again, a knight and Acre-less, what's his condition.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A gamester both ways.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Where be his spurs?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Hang in his mistress's petticoat, for which he pawned
His knighthood too, till a good hand redeem it,
He will talk you nothing but postilion's
Embroideries for his coach, and Flanders mares:
What several suits for the twelve days at Christmas,
How many ladies dote upon his physiognomy:
That he is limited but a hundred pound
A month for diet, which will scarce maintain him
In pheasant eggs an Turkey for his motion.
Now does his barge attend him, if he came
By water, but if the dice chance to run counter,
He stays till twelve in anger, devours smoke,
And desperately will shoot the bridge at midnight
Without a waterman.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: The house fills a pace
What are these ha?

div.stage: Enter a country gentleman, and Little-stocke.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: A country gentleman, and Littlestock.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A country gentleman? I have seen him sure
Appear in other shape, is he a christian?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Why? dost thou doubt him?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: 'Cause I have met him with a turban once,
If I mistake not, but his linen was not
So handsome altogether as the Turks
in cuerpo with a crabtree cudgel too,
Walking and canting broken Dutch for farthings.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: The apparition of an angel once
Brought him to this.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Dost call him country gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: His generation is not known i'th town,
You see what dice can do, now he's admired.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: For what I prithee?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: For talking nonsense, when he has lost his money
You shall meet him going up and down the ordinary
To borrow money upon his head.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: His head,
Will he go upon his head, or will he pawn it?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Pawn it, if any man will lend him money on't,
And says 'tis good security, because
He cannot be long without it, they shall have
The wit for the use too, he will talk desperately,
And swear he is the father of all the bulls
Since Adam, if all fail he has a project
To print his jests.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: His bulls you mean,

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You're right,
And dedicate 'em to the gamesters, yet he will
Seem wise sometimes, deliver his opinions
As on the bench: in beer he utters sentences,
And after sack philosophy.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Let's not be troubled with him, who are these?
Young Barnacle?
Will you endure him.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Yes, and the vinegar-bottle his man too: but now I think on't he shall excuse me, I'll lose no time; if I win, I shall have less cause to repent, if I lose, by these hilts I'll make him the cause and beat him.
Are they at play?

sp.speaker: Sel,
sp.l: Deep, deep gamesters.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Then luke with a hundred pieces.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p:
I'll follow, how now Frank? what in the name of folly
is he reading?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Save you gentlemen, save you noble gallants:
May a man lose any money? I honour, sir, your shadow.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: This is another humour.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: D'ye here the news gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What news I pray?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: The new coranto.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Good, sir, impart.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Be there no more gentlemen to hear it
Here? 'tis extraordinary fine news, in black and white,
From terra incognita.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Terra incognita?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Ay, sir, the quintessence of the world: for our four parts
Europe, Asia, Afric, and America, are as the four
Elements, and this, as the learned geographers say, is
Like coelum, a fifth essence or quintessence of the world.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Pray, sir, what news from this quintessence, it must
Needs be refined novelties.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: From Slavonia.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: That's no part of terra incognita, we know that.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: But you do not know that Slavonia I mean, 'tis
Inhabited by a nation without a head.

sp.speaker: Dwi.
sp.l: Without a head in? what part are their eyes?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Peace DwÃ®ndle: a cursed kind of people that have
Neither law, nor religion but for their own purposes:
Their country is somewhat low, and open to the sea.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Do they not fear drowning?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: They are safest in a tempest, if they be taken at any time by their enemies, and cast overboard, they turn other creatures, some rocks, some sharks, some crocodiles, and so retain part of their former nature.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What do those that dwell ashore?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: They follow their work, and make nets not only to catch
Fish, but towns and provinces: the Jews
Are innocent to 'em, and the Devil a dunce, of whose
Trade they are.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: A dangerous generation.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: In Perwiggana a fruitful country, the moon shines
All day, and the sun at night.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: That's strange, he has a moral in't have not we gentlemen that sit up all night a drinking, and go to bed when the sun rises?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: In this province the King never comes out of his palace.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: How does the court remove there?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: When he does purpose to change the air, he has an elephant richly trapped, that carries the court upon his back into what part of the kingdom he please.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: I have heard of elephants, that have carried castles.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: Snails, snails in comparison: and to increase your wonder â–ª this beast does never drink.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: I would be loath to keep him company.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: Eat, eat altogether, and what nothing but men, and of what rank or condition, none but great men, and the fattest nobility, but like your good monsieur he cares for nothing but the head, and it is confidently reported he has devoured more heads, within this three last years, than the elephant we had in England; eat penny loves in seven.

sp.speaker: Dwi.
sp.p: The devil choke him would he had London bridge in his belly too.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: The subjects of the great Duke of Lubberland has been lately in rebellion.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: I am sorry it will be inconvenient to hear out your coranto, I am weary of a little money when that's lost I may be a suitor for the rest of your news, and so I commend me to all your friends in Lubberland. Exit.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: DwÃ®ndle, didst hear this, now could I be angry.

sp.speaker: Dwi.
sp.p: Go to play then, sir, if you lose your money, you may talk roundly to 'em for they cannot be so uncivil as not to give losers' leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: But if I win.

sp.speaker: Dwi.
sp.p: Why then you may be drunk tonight and I'll â€” the caster to you.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: A curse upon these reeling dice, that last in, and in
was out of my way ten pieces; canst lend me any
Money, how have the cards dealt with thee.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: Lost, lost â€” I defy thee, if my knight recover not
I must be sober tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: O, for a hundred and all made now.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Yonder's â€” wins tyrannically, without
Mercy, he came in but with hundred pieces.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: I'll get a fancy presently.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: And how thrive the bones with his lordship

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: His lordship's bones are not well set they are maliciously bent against him they will run him quite out of all.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: More money Dwindle call my uncle: I must have it, for my honour, two hundred pieces more will serve my turn; in the mean time I will play away my cloak and some superfluous things about me.

sp.speaker: Dwi.
sp.p: By that time you are come to your shirt, I shall be here.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: He's blown up too. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: So, so, the dice in two or three such nights will be out of my debt, and I may live to be a landlord again.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You are fortune's minion master.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You would seem to be no fool, because she dotes not
Upon you gentlemen, I must take my chance; 'twas
A lucky hundred pound Jack Wilding.
What eating the boxes.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: Let us in again.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Chewing thy cud a little, I have lost all my money will
Thou hast made a fortunate night on't wot
Play no more.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: 'Tis the first time I had the grace to give off a winner
I wonot tempt the dice.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What hast won?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You do not hear me complain
I have not been so warm
this ten weeks.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: 'Tis frost in my breeches.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.p: Master hazard, I was afraid you had been gone, there's a fresh gamester come in with his pockets full of gold; he dazzles the gamesters, and no man has stock to play with him.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.p: A merchant he seems; he may be worth your retire.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Not for the exchange tonight , I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Temptation! now have I an infinite itch to this merchant's pieces.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: If thou wot have any money,
Speak before I launch out, and command it.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: A hundred pieces.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Call to the master o'th house by this token â€” thou wot venture again then?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: They may prove as lucky as thine â€” but what do I forget? the wench, the fairy at home, that expects me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: I had forgotten too, you wonot play now.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: 'Tis now upon the time.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: By any means go.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Hum, I ha' lost my money, and may recover a pretty wench. which hand? here covetousness, this lechery; money is the heavier. Will, dost hear? I'll requite thy courtesy.
