Thou hast lent me a hundred pound, I'll pay thee again, and thou shalt have for the use, the flesh device at home that expects, thou shalt supply my place will.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: You wonot lose this opportunity, and fool yourself. Exit. Acre.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: I am resolved; five hundred pieces say I'll come to him, you love the sport as well as I: tomorrow you shall thank me for't; be secret, she'll never know thee, for our conditions are to â€” neither light nor â€” and she must needs conceive 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Have you wit to apprehend the courtesy?
Let me alone: the wench, and I shall meet
Hereafter and be merry, here's my key
the merchant's money cools away: be wise
And keep conditions to use her at thy pleasure,
There will be enough for me: nay no demurs,
You have not lost your stomach to this game
Howe'er I speed tonight, we'll laugh tomorrow
How the poor wench was cozened.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: But wouldst ha' me go?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I would ha' thee ride boy, I must to the gamester
Farewell, remember not to speak a word, but
Kiss and embrace thy belly full.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: If I do not,
The punishment of an eunuch light upon me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: How now will, thou lookest desperately this morning.
Didst sleep well tonight ?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis very like
I went to sleep; but such a bedfellow!

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What ails she; was she dull?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Do not inquire
But curse yourself till noon, I am charitable
I do not bid thee hang thyself, and yet
I have cause to thank thee, I would not have lost
The turn, for all the money I won last night Jack,
Such a delicious theft.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I think so.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I found it so and dare make my affidavit.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thou didst not see her?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Nor speak to her, to what purpose.
She was so handsome i'th dark, you know
My meaning, had been pity any light
Or voice should interrupt us.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Now do I
Grow melancholy.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: If thou dost envy me
There is some reason for't, thou dost imagine
I have had pleasure in my days, but never,
Never, so sweet a skirmish, how like joy
She grew to my embraces, not a kiss
But had Elysium in't.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I was a rascal.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: If thou didst know but half so much as I
Or couldst imagine it, thou wouldst acknowledge
Thyself worse then a rascal on record.
I have not words to express, how soft, how bounteous
How every thing a man with full desires
Could wish a lady, do not question me
Further; 'tis too much happiness to remember
I am sorry I have said so much.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Was not I cursed
To lose my money, and such delicate sport?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: But that I love thee well shouldst ne'er enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I would almost cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: You would not.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: But take her, and if thou partest with her, one night more for less than both the Indies thou'lt lose by her, she has paid me for my service, I ask nothing else.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: If she be such a precious armful will
I think you may be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Take heed,
And understand thyself a little better:
I think you may be satisfied with what?
A handsome wench 'tis heresy recant it
I never shall be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: You do not purpose.
Purpose a new encounter.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: For thy sake
'Tis possible I may not, I would have
My game kept for me; what I have done
Was upon your entreaty, if you have
The like occasion hereafter I
Should have a hard heart to deny thee Jack.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thou hast fired my blood, that I could call back time,
And be possessed of what my indiscretion
gave up to thy enjoying, but I am comforted,
She thinks 'twas I, and we hereafter may
Be free in our delights: now, sir, the news
With you? Enter page.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: My mistress did command my diligence
To find you out and pray you come to speak with her.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: When I am at leisure.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: 'Tis of consequence,
She says, and much concerns you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Is Penelope â–ª
With her?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Not when she sent me forth.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Let her expect: wait you on me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I spy my blustering gamester.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: The younger ferret.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I care not if I allow thee a fit of mirth
But your boy must be in comfort.

sp.speaker: Dwi.
sp.l: Pray, sir, do not behave yourself so furiously,
Your breath is able to blow down a house, sir.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: My uncle shall build 'em up again, o Dwindle,
Thou dost not know what honour 'tis to be
So boisterous, I would take the wall now
Of my lord mayor's giants.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Do as I bid you, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Alas, sir, he'll devour me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: He sha'not hurt thee.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Be at my back then pray, sir, now I think on't
I have the beard here too with which I frighted
Our maids last night.

sp.speaker: Dwi.
sp.l: You know these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Hazard, and Wilding? how is't? how is't bulchins?
Would ye had been with us; I ha' so mauled a captain
O'th train band yonder.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Is not your name Barnacle?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Ancient Petarre?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: The admiration of the town.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: For valour.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: This inch and a half?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: There's the wonder, o the spirit, the tall spirit
Within him he has the soul of a giant.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: He has but a dwarf's body, ancient Petarre.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Sirrah, how dare you name a captain?
Thou ton of ignorance, he shall eat my pistol,
And save me the discharge.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Tell me of a tun? I'll drink twenty tons to thy
Health, who shall hinder me if I have a
Mind to't, your pistol's a peppercorn, I will eat
Up an armoury, if my stomach serve, so long as I
Have money to pay for't, and you were as little again
As you are: fright me with your potguns, my name's
Barnacle, sir, call me what you please, and my
Man's name's Dwindle, and you go there to, do not
Think but I have seen fire-drakes afore now though
I never talked on't, and rackets too, though my man
Be a coxcomb here, and balls of wildfire, no dispraise
To you; d'ye think to thunder me with your pick
Tooth by your side?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Let my sword show him but one flash of lightning
To singe the hair of his head off.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Good ancient Petarre.

sp.speaker: Dwi.
sp.l: 'Tis a very devil in decimo sexto, Peter d'ye call him?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Thou dogbolt and cozen germane to Cerbenus.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Two heads once removed, he's somewhat like him.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: I begin to think.

sp.speaker: Dwi.
sp.l: And I begin to â€”

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Again.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: He does but think.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: He think? is this a place for him to think in?
Minotaur, vanish immediately, or I will shoot death
From my mustachioes and kill thee like a porcupine.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Ancient Petarre, I know thy name and I
Honour it, thar't one of the most vainglorious
Pieces of firework that ever water wet. I am a
Gentleman, and if I have said any thing to disgust
thee, I can ask thee forgiveness, as well as the
Proudest vassal on 'em all, extend thy paw, thou
Invincible epitome of Hercules, and let thy servant
Kiss it.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Come pray, sir, be reconciled; he submits.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: I see thou hast something in thee of a soldier, to no purpose, and I will cherish it. Thou art a rascal in thy understanding, thou shalt excuse me, Turk, in honourable love: I remember thy great grandfather was hanged for robbing a pedlar-woman of six yards of inkle, and thou mayst, (Maugre the herald) in a right line, challenge the gallows by his copy; mongrel of mongrel hall. I am thy humble servant, and will cut the throat of any man that says thou hast either wit or honesty more than is fit for a gentleman. Command my sword, my lungs, my life, thou art a puff, a mulligrub, a metaphysical coxcomb, and I honour you with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: I thank you noble ancient, and kind gentlemen.
Come Dwindle, we'll go roar somewhere else.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Was ever such an off? Exit.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: The boy hid hit his humour excellently.
Here, cherish thy wit.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Now shall I tell my mistress you'll come to her?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: How officious you are for your mistress, sirrah?
What said she I came not home all night?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Nothing to me; but my eyes never beheld
Her look more pleasantly.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Now farewell Jack, I need not urge your secrecy
Touching your mistress, I have mounted for you:
Only I'll caution you, look when you meet
That you perform your business handsomely.
I ha' begun so well she may suspect else,
And put thee out of service, if she do,
You know your wages â–ª I shall laugh at thee,
And heartily; so farewell, farewell Jack. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: To say the truth I have showed myself a coxcomb.
A pox a play that made me double looser.
For ought I know, she may admit me never
To such a turn again, and then I ha' punished
myself ingeniously.
sp.stage: Enter mistress Wilding, Penelope, and mistress Leonora, a servant waiting upon them.
sp.l: My wife.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: My mistress, sir.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Keep you at distance, Penelope, and Leonora,
She's as the boy reported something more
Pleasant than ordinary.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: 'Tis he good cousin,
Pretend some business â–ª offer at some wares,
Or ask the goldsmith what your diamond's worth,
Something to trifle time away, while I
Speak with my husband a few words.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: She comes towards me.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: I can contain no longer,
How d'ye sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Well, but a little melancholy.
You look more sprightfully wife, something has pleased you.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: It has indeed, and if it be no stain
To modesty, I would inquire how you
Sped the last night.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I lost my money.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: I do not mean that game.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I am not betrayed I hope; do not mean that game?

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: You're a fine gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: 'Tis so, could she not keep her own counsel?

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: And have behaved yourself most wittily,
And I may say most wrongfully: this will
Be much for your honour, when 'tis known.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What will be known?

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Do you not blush? o fie.
Is there no modesty in man?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What riddle
Have you got now? I wonot yet seem conscious.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: 'Tis time then to be plain, it was a wonder
I could be so long silent, did you like
Your last night's lodging?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Very, very well;
I went not to bed all night.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: You did not lie with
Mistress Penelope my kinswoman?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Refuse me if I did.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: You need not swear;
But 'twas no fault of yours, no fault no virtue:
But 'tis no place to expostulate these actions.
In brief know 'twas my plot, for I observed
Which way your warm affection moved, and wrought
So with my honest cousin to supply
Her wanton place, that with some shame at last,
I might deceive your hard heart into kindness.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: That, that again sweet wife, and be a little
Serious; was it your plot to excuse your cousin,
And be the bedfellow?

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Heaven knows 'tis truth.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I am fitted, fitted with a pair of horns
Of my own making.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Thank, and think upon
That providence that would not have you lost
In such a forest of loose thoughts, and be
Yourself again; I am your handmaid still,
And have learned so much piety to conceal
Whatever should dishonour you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: It buds,
It buds already. I shall turn stark mad,
Horn mad.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: What ail you? are you vexed because
Your wantonness thrived so well?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Well with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: I did expect your thanks.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Yes, I do thank you, thank you heartily,
Most infinitely thank you.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Doth this merit
No other payment but your scorn, then know
Bad man, 'tis in my power to be revenged,
And what I had a resolution
Should sleep in silent darkness, now shall look
Day in the face, I'll publish to the world
how I am wronged, and with what stubborness
You have despised the cure of your own fame;
Nor shall my cousin suffer in her honour â–ª
I stoop as low as earth to show my duty,
But too much trampled on I rise to tell
The world I am a woman.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No, no; hark you,
I do not mock you, I am taken with
The conceit, what a fine thing I have made myself.
Ne'er speak on't, thy device shall take; I'll love thee.
And kiss thee for't, thou'st paid me handsomely:
An admirable plot, and followed cunningly,
I'll see thee anon again, and lie with thee
Tonight , without a stratagem. The gentlewomen
Expect thee; keep all close, dear wife, no sentences.
I am tricked and trimmed at my own charges rarely,
I'll seek out somebody again. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: I have presumed too much upon your patience,
I have discovered, and I hope 'twill take.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: I wish it may.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: You are sad still, Leonora.
Remove these thoughts: come I'll wait on you now
To the exchange: some toys may there strike off
Their sad remembrance.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I attend you.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: The gentleman that was yesterday to speak with you
Is come again to visit you.

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: S. Richard hurry?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: The same, sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You may admit him.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Men of his quality
Do seldom court affliction, this, I must
Allow, is a most noble gratitude
For those good offices my father did him.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Sir, the respects I owe you make me again
Solicitor for your safety, and although
on the first proposition it appear
Strange to you, and perhaps incredible,
Which might dispose you to the slow embrace
Of what I tendered, yet again brought to you
After a time to examine and consider
What most concerns you, I am confident,
You will accept, and thank me â–ª

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: Noble sir.
You do express so are is bounty, men
Will slowly imitate; I am not so
Lost in my wild misfortune, but my reason
Will guide me to acknowledge and pay back
My service and myself, for so much charity
As you have pleased to show me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Here's for thy pains: they are the same; make good
Thy word, and place me where I may unseen
Hear their discourse.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: This way.

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: But with your pardon,
I would desire to hear again how much
I shall be obliged that knowing the extent
Of your desert I may pay back a duty,
That may in every circumstance become
My fortune and the benefit.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Then thus: you are a prisoner; that alone
Is misery,
But yours the greater, in that guilt of blood,
Not sums that may be recompensed, detain you.
I'll not dispute the circumstance, Delamore
Slain by your hand.

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: I have confessed,
The first jury having found it murder.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: His blood calls to the law for justice, and you cannot
Left to yourself, and looking on the fact,
Expect with any comfort what must follow.
Yet I in pity of your sufferings,
In pity of your youth which would be else
Untimely blasted, offer to remove
your sorrows, make you free and right again,
With clear satisfaction to the law.

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: Good sir,
Pray give me leave to doubt here. I see not
Howe'er your will and charity may be active
In my desires to save me, that you can
Assure my life and freedom, since in causes
Of such high nature, laws must have their course,
Whose stream as it were wickedness to pollute,
It were vanity for any private man
To think he could resist. I speak not this
To have you imagine I despise my life,
But to express my fears your will does flatter you
'Bove what your power can reach.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: For that I urge not
My being a commissioner alone
To do you service, I have friends in court,
And great ones, when the rigor of the law
Hath sentenced you to mediate your pardon:
Nor takes it from the justice of a prince,
Where provocation and not malice makes
Guilty, to save, whom the sharp letter dooms
Sometimes to execution: I am to far
From doubting your discharge, that I dare forfeit
My life if I secure not yours from any
Danger for this offence.

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: You speak all comfort
Which way can I deserve this?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: That I'll show you.
I had an obligation to your father
Whose love when all my fortunes were i'th ebb,
And desperately, relieved me with large sums;
By whose careful manage I arrived at what
I am, and I should be a rebel to
Nature and goodness not to love the son
Of such a friend by his misfortune made
Ripe for my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Beo
sp.l: You speak your bounty,
But teach not all this while how to deserve it.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: 'Tis done by your acceptance of my daughter
To be your bride.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: To be my bride? pray tell tell me
Is she deformed or wanton, what vice has she?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Vice, sir, she will deserve as good a husband,
She is handsome though I say't, and shall be rich too.

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: She is too good, if she be fair or virtuous.
Pardon, I know she is both: but you amaze me,
I did expect conditions of danger:
A good wife is a blessing above health;
You teach me to deserve my life first from you
By offering a happiness beyond it.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: If you find love to accept, 'tis the reward
I look for, Leonora shall obey
Or quit a father.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Ha goodness defend.
I know you do but mock me, and upbraid
My act, that killed her servant: wound me still,
I have deserved her curse: I see her weep,
And every tear accuse me.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: May I never
Thrive in my prayers to heaven, if what I offer
I wish not heartily confirmed.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: I now
Suspect you are not Leonora father,
'Twere better you dissembled, then made her
So passed all hope of being cured again:
I marry Leonora! can her soul
Think on so foul a rape, she cannot sure.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: She shall; I command.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: By virtue, but
She sha'not, nor would I to grasp an empire
Tempt her to so much stain, let her tell down
Her virgin tears, on Delamore's cold marble,
Sigh to his dust, and call revenge upon
His head whose anger sent him to those shades,
From whence she ne'er must see him; this will justify
She loved the dead: it were impiety
One smile should bless her murderer, and howe'er
you are pleased to compliment with my affliction,
I know she cannot find one thought without her
So foul to look upon me.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.p: Let it rest on that, will you confirm and timely make provision for your safety?

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: For my life
You mean, now on the chance, than I may live
You are confident, and think it not impossible
Your daughter may affect me â–ª there's at once
Two blessings, are they not and mighty ones,
Considering what I am, how low, how lost
To th' common air?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Now you are wise.

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: But if
Your daughter would confirm this, and propound
Herself my victory.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: I should condemn her, and despise the conquest â–ª
These things may bribe an atheist not a lover.
But you perhaps are ignorant, I have given
My faith away irrevocably, 'tis
The wealth of Violante, and I wonot
Basely steal back a thought, and yet I thank you,
I am not so inhumane.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Will you not
Prefer your life
To honour and religion?

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: For shame be silent could you make me lord
Of my own destiny, and that Leonora
Had empires for her dower, and courted me
With all the flatteries of life, to quit
My vows to Violante, I would die
Upon her bosom to meet death â–ª

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: And death
You must expect which will take off this bravery.

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: And I will kiss it, kiss it, like a bride.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: So resolute?

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: And if I cannot live
My Violantes, I will die her sacrifice.
Good sir, no more, you do not well to trouble
The quiet of a prisoner thus that cannot
Be a too careful steward of those minutes
Left him to make his peace, tempt me no further:
The earth is not so fixed as my resolves,
Rather to die then in one thought transplant
My love from Violante.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Be undone,
And this contempt shall hasten the divorce
Of soul and love, die and be soon forgotten. Exit.

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: My Violante, if there can be any joy
Neighbour too so much grief, I'll pour it out
To pay thy bounteous visit, if my eyes
Admit no fellowship in weeping, 'tis
Because my heart which saw thee first, would bid
Thee welcome thither, scorning; to acknowledge
There can be any thing but joy where thou art.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: But sadness my dear Beaumont, while there is
A cause that makes thee prisoner, I must weep
And empty many springs, my eyes are now
No prophets of thy sorrow but the witness,
And when I think of death that waits upon thee
I wither to a ghost.

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: Why Violante,
We must all die, restrain these weeping fountains,
Keep 'em till I am dead, dispense 'em then
Upon my grave, and I shall grow again,
And in the sweet disguise of a fair garden
Salute the spring that gave me green and odour.
Why should not love transform us?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Be not lost
In these imaginations.

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: Or perhaps
Th' â–ª hast ambition, she whose love made up
A wonder to the world beside the pledge
Of duty to her lord, famed Artemisia
Shall be no more in story for her tomb:
For on the earth that weighs my body down
when I am dead, thy tears by the cold breath
Of heaven congealed to Beaumont's memory,
Shall raise a monument of pearl to our do
The great Mausolus' sepulchre.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: No more
Of this vain language, if you have any pity
On the poor Violante.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I ha' done,
And yet I am going now to a long silence;
Allow my sorrow to take leave Violante

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: It shall be so, be valiant my heart
Beaumont I come not to take leave of thee.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Perhaps you'll see me again.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Again and often,
Thy stars are gentle to thee, many days,
And years are yet between thee and that time
That threatens loss of breath; see, I can thus
Disperse the clouds sat heavy on my brow,
Wipe the moisture hence, 'tis day again;
Take beams into thy eye, and let them sink
Upon thy better fortune, live, live happily.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Is Delamore alive?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Dead and interred.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: From what can this hope rise?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: From thyself Beaumont;
If thou wilt save thyself, I have heard all,
And by the duty of my love am bound
To hide your resolution, can you be
So merciless to yourself to refuse life
When it is offered with the best advantage
Is Leonora's love? A price that should
Buy you from all the world? be counselled sir,
O, do not lose yourself in a vain passion
For thought of me, I cancel all your vows,
And give you back your heart, be free again
If you will promise me to live and love.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Leonora.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: That best of womankind, a mine of sweetness.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: But can you leave me then?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I justify
Thy choice of me in that, that to preserve thee
Dare give thee back again, be Leonora's,
For being mine thou'rt lost to all the world
Better a thousand times, thou be made hers
Then we both loose, I'll pawn my faith she'll love thee
I'll be content to hear my Beaumont's well,
And visit thee sometimes like a glad sister,
And never beg a kiss, but if I weep
At any time when we are together,
Do not believe 'tis sorrow makes my eyes
So wet, but joy to see my Beaumont living:
As it is now to hope.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: If thou dost mean thus
Thou dost the more to inflame me to be constant,
Be not a miracle and I may be tempted
To love my life above thee, by this kiss,
O, give me but another in my death
It will restore me by this innocent hand,
While as I wish my soul I wonot leave thee
For the world's kingdom.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: But you must, unless
You change for Leonora, think of that,
Think ere you be too rash.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: I'll think of thee,
And honour to be read, I love Violante
But never could deserve her, live thou happy,
And by thy virtue teach a nearer way
To heaven, we may meet yonder, do not make me
More miserable than I am, by adding perjury
To my bloody sin, the memory of thee
Will at my execution advance
My spirit to a â€” that men shall think
I have changed my cause for martyrdom.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Then here
As of a dying man I take my leave,
Farewell unhappy Beaumont, I'll pray for thee.

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: 'Tis possible I may live yet and be thine.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: These tears embalm thee
if in this world we never meet
My life is buried in thy winding sheet.

sp.speaker: Beo.
sp.l: This exceeds all my sorrow.

div.head: Act. v.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I am justly punished now for all my tricks,
And pride o'th flesh, I had ambition
To make men cuckolds, now the devil has paid me,
Paid me i'th same coin, and I'll compare
My forehead with the broadest of my neighbours:
But ere it spreads too monstrous, I must have
Some plot upon this hazard, he supposes
He has enjoyed Penelope, and my trick
To drive the opinion home, to get him marry her
And make her satisfaction: the wench
Has oft commended him, he may be won to't,
I never meant to part with all her portion,
Perhaps he'll thank me for the moiety.
And this disposed on she's conjured to silence.
It must be so.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Jack Wilding how is't man?
How goes the plough at home? what says the lady
Guinever that was humbled in your absence?
You have the credit with her, all the glory
Of my night's work; does she not hide her eyes,
And blush, and cry you are a fine gentleman.
Turn a toside, or drop a handkercher,
And stoop, and take occasion to leer,
And laugh upon thee?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Nothing less, I know not
What thou'st done to her, but she's very sad.

sp.speaker: Ha
sp.l: Sad; I'll be hanged then.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thou must imagine
I did the best to comfort her â–ª

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: She's melancholy
for my absence man, I'll keep her company
Again tonight .

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: She thinks 'twas I enjoyed her.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Let her think whom she will, so we may couple.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: And nothing now but sighs, and cries I have
Undone her.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: She's a fool, I hurt her not,
She cried not out I am sure, and for my body
I defy the college of physicians:
Let a jury of virgins search me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: To be plain,
Although she has no thought but I was her bedfellow,
You are the only argument of her sadness.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: When I had merrily
Excused what had been done, she fetched a sight,
And with some tears revealed her love to you,
That she had loved you long, but by this act
Of mine, d'ye mark, she was become unworthy
To hope for so good fortune, I cannot tell,
But she is strangely passionate.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: For me?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: For you, but thou art soft and tender-hearted,
And in that confidence I did forbear
To tell her who had done the deed.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You did so:
'Twas wisely done â–ª now I collect myself,
She has sometime smiled upon me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Nay believe it
She is taken with thee above all the world.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: And yet she was content you should
Above all the world.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: But 'twas your better fate
To be the man, it was her destiny
To have the right performance, thou art a gentleman â–ª
And canst not but consider the poor gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What wod'st ha' me do?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Make her amends, and marry her.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Marry a strumpet?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: You had first possession,
And thou'st been married earlier couldst but had
Her maidenhead, besides nobody knows but we ourselves.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Be not abused I had
No maiden head.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: My greater torment: come, come thou art modest;
Heaven knows she may be desperate.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: A fair riddance,
We have enough o'th tribe, I am sorry I cannot
Furnish her expedition with a pair
Of my own garters.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I â€” of Athens grown,
I know thou art more charitable, she may prove
A happy wife, what woman but has frailty?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Let her make the best on't, set up shop
I'th strand, or Westminster, she may have custom,
And come to speak most learnedly i'th nose
Bid her keep quarter with the constable.
And justice's clerk and she in time may purchase.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: She has a portion will maintain her like
A gentlewoman and your wife.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Where is't?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: In my possession, and I had rather thou
Shouldst have it then another.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Thank you heartily,
A single life has single care, pray keep it.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Come thou shalt know I love thee, thou shalt have
More by a thousand pound, than I resolved
To part with cause I would call thee cozen too;
A brace of thousands will, she has to her portion,
I hoped to put her off with half the sum;
That's truth some younger brother would ha' thanked me,
And given my quietus tush, 'tis frequent
With men that are so trusted, is't a match,

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Two thousand pound will make a maidenhead
That's crooked straight again.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thou'rt in the right,
Or for the better sound, as the grammarians
Say, I will call it twenty hundred pound
byâ€™r lady a pretty stock, enough and need be,
To buy up half the maidenheads in a county.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Here's my hand I'll consider on't no further,
Is she prepared?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Leave that to me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I'll instantly about it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Ha, ha.
The project moves better than I expected,
What pains he takes out of his ignorance?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Oh! sir I am glad I ha' found you.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I was not lost.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: My nephew, sir, my nephew.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What of him.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: He's undone, he's undone, you have undone him.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: You have made him, sir, so valiant I am afraid
He's not long lived, he quarrels now with everybody
And rores and domineers and shakes the pen-houses.
A woman that sold pudding-pies, but took
The wall on him, and he trips up her heels,
And down fell all, the kennel ran pure whitepot
What shall I do I fear he will be killed:
I take a little privilege myself
Because I threaten to disinherit him,
But nobody else dares talk or meddle with him
Is there no way to take him down again
And make him coward?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: There are ways to tame him.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Now I wish heartily you had beaten him
For the hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: That may be done yet

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Is't not too late? but do you think 'twill humble him?
I expect every minute he's abroad
To hear he has killed somebody , or receive him
Brought home with half his brains or but one leg.
Good sir.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll pay you for't
If you will beat him soundly, sir, and leave him
But as you found him; for if he continue
A blade and be not killed, he wonot scape
The gallows long, and 'tis not for my honour
He should be hanged

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I shall deserve as much,
To allay this mettle, as I did to quicken it.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Nay 'tis my meaning to content you, sir.
And I shall take it as a favour too,
If for the same price you made him valiant,
You will unblade him: here's the money sir,
As weighty gold as tother; cause you should not
Lay it on lightly; break no limb, and bruise him
Three-quarters dead, I care not; he may live
Many a fair day after it.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You show
An uncle's love in this, trust me to cure
His valour.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: He is here; do but observe.
And beat him, sir, accordingly.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: How now uncle?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Thou art no nephew of mine, thar't a rascal
I'll be at no more charge to make thee a gentleman,
Pay for your dice and drinkings, I shall have
The surgeon's bills brought shortly home to me,
Be troubled to bail thee from the sessions,
And afterwards make friends to the recorder
For a reprieve, yes, I will see thee hanged first.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: And be at the charge to paint the gallows too;
If I have a mind the waits shall play before me,
And I'll be hanged in state three storeys high, uncle:
But first I'll cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Bless me, defend me.

sp.speaker: Acr
sp.l: How now, what â–ª s the matter?

sp.speaker: Sel
sp.l: Master Barnacle?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: There's an ungracious bird of mine own nest,
will murder me.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: He wonot sure?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Put up,
And ask your uncle presently forgiveness;
Or I will hough thee.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Hough me? I will put up
At thy entreaty.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Gentlemen you remember
This noble gallant.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: Cousin of yours I take it.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Cousin to a killing, in your company
Lent me a box o'th ear.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: No, no, I gave it,
I gave it freely; keep it, never think on't,
I can make bold with thee another time,
Would 't'had been twenty.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: One's too much to keep.
I am a gamester, and remembered always
To pay the box; there's first your principal,
Take that for the use.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Use? would thou'dst given my uncle.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: They have cost him already two hundred pounds
And upwards, shotten herring, thing of noise.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: O, for my man Dwindle
And his basket-hilt now my uncle shall rue this.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Down presently, and before these gentlemen
Desire his pardon.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: How, desire his pardon?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Then let this go round.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: I will ask his pardon, I beseech you uncle.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: And swear.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: And do swear.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: To be obedient, never more to quarrel.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Why look you gentlemen, I hope you are persuaded
By being sick so patiently, that I am
Not over valiant.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I suspect him still.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: For more assurance do you kick me too.
Am not I patient and obedient now?
Will you have any more gentlemen, before I rise?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: If ever he prove rebellious in act,
Or language, let me know it.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Will you not give
Me leave to roar abroad a little for
My credit?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Never, sirrah, now I'll tame you.
I thank you gentlemen, command me for
This courtesy.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: 'Tis possible I may
With less noise grow more valiant hereafter:
Till then I am in all your debts.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.l: Be ruled,
And be my nephew again: this was my love,
My love dear nephew.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: If your love consist
In kicking uncle, let me love you again,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Follow me, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Acr.
sp.l: Then his uncle paid for't?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Heartily, heartily.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: I thought there was some trick.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: And whether are you going gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: We are going to visit Beomont in the prison.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: 'Tis charity, but that I have deep engagements,
I'd wait upon you, but commend my service to him,
I'll visit him ere night; you saw not Wilding?

sp.speaker: A.l.s.
sp.l: We saw his wife and kinswoman enter
Sr. Richard hurries half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Ha â–ª
sp.l: His kinswoman? I thank you.
You have saved me travail, farewell gentlemen,
Farewell.

div.stage: Enter Leonora, and Violante, mistress Wilding; and Penelope.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: My father has some design, and bade me send for thee.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: You're both too sad, come, come, we must divert
This melancholy.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I beseech your pardon,
But is my Beomont sent for?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes: we are
Too private.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I much fear Leonora now,
She looks not sad enough, although I could â–ª
Resign my interest freely to preserve him,
I would not willingly be present when
They interchange hearts, sly will show too much
A tyrant, if she be not satisfied
With what was mine, but I must be moiety
To be their triumph.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: Master hazard?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: All things
Succeed beyond your thought, pray give me a little
Opportunity with your kinswoman. Exit. Mi. Leo. Vio.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: We'll withdraw.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I know not how to woo her now, sweet lady?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Your pleasure, sir?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Pray let me ask you a question.
If you had lost your way and met one,
A traveller like myself, that knew the coast
O'th country, would you thank him to direct you?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: That common manners would instruct.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I think so.

sp.speaker: Pene,
sp.l: But there are many ways to the wood, and which
Would you desire, the nearest path, and safest
Or that which leads about?
Without all question.
The nearest and the safest.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Can you love then?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: I were a devil else:

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: And can you love a man?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: A man, what else, sir?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You're so far on your way. Now love but me,
You're at your journey's end, what say to me?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Nothing, sir.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: That's no answer, you must say something.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: I hope you'll not compel me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: D'ye hear lady?
Setting this foolery aside: I know
You cannot choose but love me.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I have been told so.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: You are easy of belief
I think I should be best acquainted with
My own thoughts, and I dare not be so desperate
To conclude.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Come you lie; I could have given't
In smother phrase: you're a dissembling gentlewoman.
I know your heart, you have loved me a great while.
What should I play the fool? if you remember
I urged some wild discourse in the behalf
Of your lewd kinsman, 'twas a trial of thee
That humour made me love thee; and since that thy virtue.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Indeed sir?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Indeed, sir? why I have been contracted to thee.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: How long?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: This half hour, know thy portion, and shall have it.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Strange.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Nay I'll have thee too.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: You will?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I cannot help it; thy kind cozen will have it so:
'Tis his own plot, to make thee amends, is't not
Good mirth? but 'tis not love to thee or me,
But to have me possessed he is no cuckold:
I see through his device, thou art much beholding to him:
He meant to have put thee off with half thy portion,
But that if things come out we should keep counsel.
Say is't a match? I have two thousand pound too
I thank the dice, let's put our stocks together,
Children will follow; he is here already.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: So close! I am glad on't, this prepares, will hazard,
And my young cousin; a word Penelope.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Now will he make all sure.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: You used me coarsely,
But I have forgotten it, what discourse have you
with this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: He would seem to be a suitor.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Entertain him; d'ye hear, you may do worse, be ruled.
'Twas in my thought to move it, does he not
Talk strangely?

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Of nothing, let me counsel you
To love him, call him husband.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: I resolve
Never to marry without your consent.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Gentlemen, welcome.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: If you bestow me, sir, I will be confident
I am not lost, I must confess I love him.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No more: then lose no time, kind gentlemen,
You're come most seasonably to be the witnesses
Of my consent, I have examined both
Your hearts, and freely give thee here my kinswoman:
No sooner shall the church pronounce your married
But challenge what is hers.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Two thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I do confess it is her portion
You sha'not stay to talk, nay gentlemen,
Pray see the business finished.

sp.speaker: A.l.s.
sp.l: We attend you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: So, so, this will confirm him in the opinion,
Penelope was the creature he enjoyed,
And keep off all suspicion of my wife,
Who is still honest in the imagination
That only I embraced her, all secure,
And my brows smooth again, who can deride me?
But I myself, ha, that's too much I know it,
And spite of these tricks am a Cornelius.
Cannot I bribe my conscience to be ignorant?
Why then I ha' done nothing, yes advanced
The man, that grafted shame upon my forehead:
Vexation, parted with two thousand pound,
And am no less a cuckold then before
Was I predestined to this shame and mockery?
Where were my brains? yet why am I impatient?
Unless betrayed he cannot reach the knowledge,
And then no matter â€” yes I am cursed again,
My torment multiplies, how can he think
He played the wanton with Penelope
When he finds her a maid? that ruins all:
I would she had been strumpeted, he knows
My wife's virginity to well, I am lost,
And must be desperate, kill him; no, my wife.
Not so good, death is over black and horrid,
And I am grown ridiculous to myself.
I must do some thing.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Master Wilding, welcome,
You've been a great a stranger.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Know you?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: They say I am much altered o'late.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: There is some alteration in your forehead.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: My forehead?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: 'Tis not smooth enough, you're troubled:
Your wife's within.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: She loves your daughter, sir.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: When saw you master Beaumont?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Not today.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: I have sent for him; pray stay, and witness
His further examination, I propounded
A way to do him good but he is obstinate.
Would I could change condition with him!

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: He is not troubled now with being a cuckold,
You shall command.

div.stage: Enter mistress Wilding, and a servant.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Your husband lady,

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Wife you are a whore
You shall know more hereafter,
I must go live i'th forest.

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: And I i'th common.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: She'll turn prostitute.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Attend him hither. Master Beaumont's come
nay you shall favour me so much, here's the gentleman
Already.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Sir, your pleasure? by your command I am brought hither,
I hope you have no more to charge me with
Then freely I have confessed.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I must answer
You can have but my life to satisfy;
Pray speak my accusation.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Besides the offence known and examined
You are guilty
Of that which all good natures do abhor.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: You have a privilege, but do not make me
Good sir, to appear monstrous, who are my
Accusers?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: I am one.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And my judge too:
I have small hope to plead then, but proceed,
And name my trespass.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: That which includes all
That man should hate; ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Bea
sp.l: You have
Preferred a large indictment, and are the first
That ever charged me with't, it is a stain
My soul held most at distance, but descend
To some particular; this offence doth rise
Or fall in the degree, or reference
To persons sinned against, to whom have I
Been so ingrateful?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Ingrate as high as murder.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Thyself, to whom that life thou oughtest to cherish
Thou hast undone

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I am not so uncharitable
Howe'er you please to urge it, but I know
Why you conclude so, let me, sir, be honest
To heaven and my own heart, and then if life
Will follow, it shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Still perverse:
Stand forth my Leonora, look upon her.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I see a comely frame which cannot be
Without as fair a mind.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: With her I make
Once more a tender of my wealth and thy
Enlargement.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: How can you discharge him, sir?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Take you no care for that, it shall be secured
If he accept, 'tis the last time of asking,
Answer to purpose now.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: There shall need none,
Sir, to forbid this marriage, but myself;
My resolution but warm before
Is now a flame I honour this fair virgin,
And am too poor to thank your love, but must not
Buy life with so much shame, I am Violante,
My last breath shall confirm it.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Beaumont think on't
A little better, be not mad; if this be possible
Embrace her instantly.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: She does not look
With any countenance of love upon me:
See, she does weep.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: She'll love thee afterwards.
And she do not, she can but cuckold thee
There be more i'th parish man.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Since you are so peremptory
So peremptory: here receive your sentence.
Live and love happily.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: My dearest Beaumont.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: To what purpose is this? he must be hanged for Delamore.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Here's one can clear the danger.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: The surgeon? did not you say he was dead?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: I did, to serve his ends, which you see noble:
Delamore is past danger, but wants strength
To come abroad.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You give me another life.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: I see heaven has decreed him for thy husband,
And shalt have my consent too.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now you bless me.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: I wished to call thee son, pardon my trial
Joy ever in your bosoms.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I feel a blessing
That only can be thought, silence my tongue,
And let our hearts discourse.

div.stage: Enter Hazard, Penelope, Acre-less, Little-stocke, and Sel-away

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You leave gentlefolks; who wishes joy.
And a bundle of boys the first night?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Married.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Fast as the priest could tie us.

sp.speaker: A.s.l.
sp.l: We are witnesses.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Cousin two thousand pound, and lady now
'Tis time to clear all.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I'll be divorced now
Wife you're a whore.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Ho there, no bug-words, come
We must tell something in your care. Be merry
You are no cuckold, make no noise, I know
That's it, offends your stomach.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I touched not her, nor this with one rude action.
We'll talk the circumstance when you come home.
Your wife expected you, but when I came
She had prepared light, and her cousin here
To have made you blush and chide you into honesty
Seeing their chaste simplicities, was won
To silence, which brought on my better fortune.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Can this be real

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.l: By my hopes of peace
I'th tother world you have no injury:
My plot was only to betray you to
Love and repentance.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.l: Be not troubled, sir,
I am a witness of my cousin's truth,
And hope you'll make all prosper, in renewing
Your faith to her.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Be wise and no more words
Thou hast a treasure in thy wife, make much on her:
For any act of mine, she is as chaste
As when she was new born. Love love her Jack.
As when she was new born. Love; love her Jack.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I am ashamed, pray give me all forgiveness â–ª
I see my follies, heaven invites me gently
To thy chaste bed, be thou again my dearest,
Thy virtue shall instruct me: joy to all:
Here be more. â€” Delamore is living,
And Leonora marked to enjoy him,
Violante is possessed of Beaumont too.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: These be love's miracles: a spring tide flow
In every bosom.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: This day let me feast you
Anon we'll visit Delamore.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: My soul
Longs to salute him.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Here all folly's die.
May never gamester have worse fate than I.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
